thread.title_full: Candidates for Charleston City Council, District 3 - Post and Courier

author: postandcourier.com
text:
Jimmy Bailey Jimmy Bailey Age: 40
Residence: Hampton Park Terrace
Occupation: Community management executive
Education: Bachelors degree in English, University of South Carolina; certificate, Graduate School of Banking at Louisiana State University
 872-9842, jimmybaileyjr@gmail.com , www.jimmybaileyjr.com
 Children’s activities, boat, beach, large extended family
 Professionally, I’ve had responsibility for constituent service, infrastructure, large budgets, recreation, architectural review, security, and many services typically seen in a municipality.
 Constituent service, pushing for bolder action than we’ve had in the past on traffic and congestion, advocating for smarter growth management, and supporting public schools .
James Lewis Jr. Age: 66
Residence: West Side
Occupation: Retired Department Manager for Piggly Wiggly, Inc.
Education: Attended Cummins Theological Seminary
 1995
Contact information: (843) 901-3897, james.lewisjr2011@comcast.net , www.jameslewisjr.com
 Working on problems, issues and concerns for my constituents.
 I serve my constituents faithfully; I work with the mayor and City Council members to ensure that the city of Charleston is safe, and that we have a balanced budget.
 Affordable housing, crime reduction, keeping taxes down, and providing elite constituent services for a better quality of life for all citizens.
Luqman S. Rasheed Age: 63
Residence: North Central neighborhood
Occupation: Trucking industry maintenance; retired plumber and taxi driver
Education: Certification from the United Association Plumbers & Pipefitters
 566-3481, imamrasheedls@yahoo.com
 Community service, playing saxophone, Sunday school instructor, family vacations.
 For nearly 20 years, I have served the Charleston community as an advocate for education, beautification and public safety. My leadership and service will continue to voice citizens’ concerns.
 Education and working to improve failing schools; housing, by allocating a specific percentage of new housing for living-wage workers; and transportation by developing a transportation hub north of Mount Pleasant Street.
